Okay, I jumped too soon on this question. I just found this described in Harry's translation of Nihonto Kozo Vol. 6 in his glossery (page Glossery 3):

"Chikaragane: Reinforcement tabs on the back of the menuki. Chikara means strength, Gane is metal." 

Interesting!  

Ron
STL


----- Original Message ----- 
From: Ron Hartmann 
To: TOKEN ; nihontostudy ; nihonto@yahoogroups.com 
Sent: Wednesday, July 08, 2009 1:06 PM
Subject: Sword term meaning...


What does the term "chikara gane" mean when refering to the back of menuki? On something AY translated for me decades ago he wrote, "...in the base, chikara gane comes to be used." This is a translation describing menuki from mid-Edo period. (Kinko Mino bori p.109)

Ron
STL
